text:
Rik took the pain of re-implementing an entire code editor from scratch, even down to glyph rendering. He would tweet the process, which took many months. There would be a tweet every now and then along the lines of "tried such and such parsing/layout/etc library, not fast enough. rolling my own." The result is an editor that is just _fast_*™*.

To me, that is the unique FOC aspect of makepad. Speed is meant to enable the kinds of exploration that are only possible when things work fast.

elements.text: Rik took the pain of re-implementing an entire code editor from scratch, even down to glyph rendering. He would tweet the process, which took many months. fast

.

To me, that is the unique FOC aspect of makepad. Speed is meant to enable the kinds of exploration that are only possible when things work fast.

text: Question: Do you think performance is to some extent a blind spot in the rest of the FOC community?

text: Hi people, i made makepad. i can answer questions

elements.text: Hi people, i made makepad. i can answer questions

text: Makepad is a new UI stack written in Rust with 0-dep backends for win32/dx11 linux/opengl mac/metal and web/webgl

elements.text: Makepad is a new UI stack written in Rust with 0-dep backends for win32/dx11 linux/opengl mac/metal and web/webgl

text: it has its own live code editor, visual editors, and runs in VR too

elements.text: it has its own live code editor, visual editors, and runs in VR too

text: the first use of the thing will be to make a new shader coding env on the web by using its live-code features like colorpickers and animtimelines

elements.text: the first use of the thing will be to make a new shader coding env on the web by using its live-code features like colorpickers and animtimelines

text: some neat features of makepad: It uses shaders as UI styling constructs (like CSS but without the C and the suck suck)

elements.text: some neat features of makepad: It uses shaders as UI styling constructs (like CSS but without the C and the suck suck)

text:
<@UFB8STN7K> asked:
> I’m actually mystified at the real-time compilation. Is that because it’s a completely different compiler using a Rust skin?

elements.text: asked:
I’m actually mystified at the real-time compilation. Is that because it’s a completely different compiler using a Rust skin?

text: we have our own shader syntax which is a hybrid of GLSL and Rust, and a shader compiler to target all those backend languages

elements.text: we have our own shader syntax which is a hybrid of GLSL and Rust, and a shader compiler to target all those backend languages

text: the UI is a new kind of imgui with 2 flows instead of 1

elements.text: the UI is a new kind of imgui with 2 flows instead of 1

text: the layoutsystem is 'inline' with the drawflow so its extremely simple and fast but can still do most of the things you'd want from a layout system.

elements.text: the layoutsystem is 'inline' with the drawflow so its extremely simple and fast but can still do most of the things you'd want from a layout system.

text: it should compile in about 20-30 seconds with all dependencies

elements.text: it should compile in about 20-30 seconds with all dependencies

text:
I think so, to an extent. To unfairly pick on just one example, there's the <https://penrose.ink/siggraph20.html|Penrose> project that Katherine Ye worked on. In their demos it appears to run so slowly that I think I would rather lay things out by hand. A lot of projects take the approach of making it first, then making it fast, and that rarely works out in my experience.

In the case of Makepad, isn't speed the whole point, though? Rik was (AFAIK) just trying to make a better version of an existing thing, rather than invent something new.

elements.text: I think so, to an extent. To unfairly pick on just one example, there's the
Penrose

project that Katherine Ye worked on. In their demos it appears to run so slowly that I think I would rather lay things out by hand. A lot of projects take the approach of making it first, then making it fast, and that rarely works out in my experience.

In the case of Makepad, isn't speed the whole point, though? Rik was (AFAIK) just trying to make a better version of an existing thing, rather than invent something new.

text: So i simply wanted to start improving developertools, and bridge the gap to designers

text: At first i used MSDF, which worked great actually except on lowDPI, then we switched to 'pathfinder-2' style GPU atlasses. So we GPU accelerate (but not super fast) render our atlasses for a certain subpixel position+size

text: Yeah that’s fair. We played around with MSDF as well but balked when we realized the textures would be ~40gb for unicode haha. Interesting that it did poorly in lowDPI, we hadn’t played with it long enough to discover that one. :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Yeah that’s fair. We played around with MSDF as well but balked when we realized the textures would be ~40gb for unicode haha. Interesting that it did poorly in lowDPI, we hadn’t played with it long enough to discover that one.

text: yea so we load our own TTF's and render the atlasses entirely on demand. So luckily no 40gb textures

text: Thanks! We're going for 'new shadertoy' because shaders give me a live backend, also the system has some really interesting answers to improve shaderprogramming. Things will rapidly happen now.

elements.text: Thanks! We're going for 'new shadertoy' because shaders give me a live backend, also the system has some really interesting answers to improve shaderprogramming. Things will rapidly happen now.

text: You do consulting inbetween your failures :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: You do consulting inbetween your failures

text: And you don't give up. Because my early experiments showed the performance was there. Even in 2013. The problem was how do you layer a programming model on top that actually scales.

elements.text: And you don't give up. Because my early experiments showed the performance was there. Even in 2013. The problem was how do you layer a programming model on top that actually scales.

text: It had to come from Wasm + Rust before that clicked.

elements.text: It had to come from Wasm + Rust before that clicked.

text: That animated code folding makepad has i couldn't do in JS no matter how hard i tried. Its a font-size animation that runs with full layout and everything.

elements.text: That animated code folding makepad has i couldn't do in JS no matter how hard i tried. Its a font-size animation that runs with full layout and everything.

text: With Rust (and Wasm) its the first time i actually have breathing room in my CPU performance. On native i'm regularly in the 1-3 millisecond per update/edit/fold cpu time

elements.text: With Rust (and Wasm) its the first time i actually have breathing room in my CPU performance. On native i'm regularly in the 1-3 millisecond per update/edit/fold cpu time

text: Yeah, I’ve found ways to get JS there, but you can’t write anything that actually looks like JS to do it. The backend for the language we’ve been writing is built so that it can pretty trivially emit whatever. It’ll be interesting to try some c-like JS vs Rust vs Rust compiled WASM vs direct to WASM at some point :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Yeah, I’ve found ways to get JS there, but you can’t write anything that actually looks like JS to do it. The backend for the language we’ve been writing is built so that it can pretty trivially emit whatever. It’ll be interesting to try some c-like JS vs Rust vs Rust compiled WASM vs direct to WASM at some point

text: I don’t have SIMD and a few other things I’d like to have in JS-land, but it gets us instant hotswapping across the whole system.

elements.text: I don’t have SIMD and a few other things I’d like to have in JS-land, but it gets us instant hotswapping across the whole system.

text: I’ve been thinking of it as a tiered thing. Develop in the dynamic, slightly slower mode, then spit it out to rust on deploy.

elements.text: I’ve been thinking of it as a tiered thing. Develop in the dynamic, slightly slower mode, then spit it out to rust on deploy.

text: Yea that would be the ideal situation. I'm solving it by moving certain domains (UI styling, shaders, layout) into the 'live' coding, and the rest will simply have to wait for a Rust recompile cycle. Which isnt THAT long to be fair.

elements.text: Yea that would be the ideal situation. I'm solving it by moving certain domains (UI styling, shaders, layout) into the 'live' coding, and the rest will simply have to wait for a Rust recompile cycle. Which isnt THAT long to be fair.

text: It's very hard to know when you want what yr livecoding to be 'as fast as it gets' or interpreted. The gap is so vast, especially in creative domains

elements.text: It's very hard to know when you want what yr livecoding to be 'as fast as it gets' or interpreted. The gap is so vast, especially in creative domains

text: The most inspiring solution i have yet come across is leonard ritters ' 'Scopes' language. It keeps llvm online to runtime compile bits of 'eval' language

elements.text: The most inspiring solution i have yet come across is leonard ritters ' 'Scopes' language. It keeps llvm online to runtime compile bits of 'eval' language

text: Problem is that as soon as you move your performance domain into 'really needs LLVM optimisation' yr kinda stuck waiting for that. Because running it in 'slow' mode doesn't really do it anymore. I made makepad run on Rust-debug builds by building a nearly 10x performance window in it (ie i use <10% cpu at all time)

elements.text: Problem is that as soon as you move your performance domain into 'really needs LLVM optimisation' yr kinda stuck waiting for that. Because running it in 'slow' mode doesn't really do it anymore. I made makepad run on Rust-debug builds by building a nearly 10x performance window in it (ie i use <10% cpu at all time)

text: Now when i compile it for the Quest in wasm i need every ounce of that performance I just 'barely' scrape through the door there.

elements.text: Now when i compile it for the Quest in wasm i need every ounce of that performance I just 'barely' scrape through the door there.

text: Yeah, I’m trying to avoid relying on LLVM primarily by generating code that needs very little optimization to be fast. We compile the language down to a very small set of semantics around just bare arrays and simple primitives.

elements.text: Yeah, I’m trying to avoid relying on LLVM primarily by generating code that needs very little optimization to be fast. We compile the language down to a very small set of semantics around just bare arrays and simple primitives.

text: Yea i considered that option, but luckily Rust saved me from going down the even longer path :slightly_smiling_face: Looking forward to see what you come up with. Still eve-ish? Or something new

elements.text: Yea i considered that option, but luckily Rust saved me from going down the even longer path
Looking forward to see what you come up with. Still eve-ish? Or something new

text: Something new. Not explicitly trying to go for accessibility this time, though where we’re landing may end up that way by accident. Mostly trying to see what happens if we tried to make just ourselves super human. We’ve learned a lot since the end of Eve and figured out how to solve a bunch of the issues we ran into. E.g. I don’t think performance is going to be a problem this time heh.

elements.text: Something new. Not explicitly trying to go for accessibility this time, though where we’re landing may end up that way by accident. Mostly trying to see what happens if we tried to make just ourselves super human. We’ve learned a lot since the end of Eve and figured out how to solve a bunch of the issues we ran into. E.g. I don’t think performance is going to be a problem this time heh.

text: Yeah im definitely not going for accessibility. Makepad is mostly an excercise in how to make building code-editors, ide's an complex designtool UI performant, and suck least to write.  Any fallout it can gather for broader appeal will have to come from a domain like Shaders.

elements.text: Yeah im definitely not going for accessibility. Makepad is mostly an excercise in how to make building code-editors, ide's an complex designtool UI performant, and suck least to write.  Any fallout it can gather for broader appeal will have to come from a domain like Shaders.

text: I should really invite L Ritter here... I'm not sure if he knows about the community but it seems like he might be into it

elements.text: I should really invite L Ritter here... I'm not sure if he knows about the community but it seems like he might be into it

text: The Quest support looks pretty slick, how far do you want to go with VR support and do you plan on doing a native VR app at some point (either targeting Quest, OpenXR, OpenVR or Rift/Rift-S)?

elements.text: The Quest support looks pretty slick, how far do you want to go with VR support and do you plan on doing a native VR app at some point (either targeting Quest, OpenXR, OpenVR or Rift/Rift-S)?

text: VR support right now is more of an experiment. I've always said the UI tech would work in VR, so now we are proving that. I think it could be really nice 'extra' if our webbased shader editor has a VR mode that also works. For now we stick to webXR, but integrating a nativeVR platform probably isin the order of a week of work so its not that hard.

elements.text: VR support right now is more of an experiment. I've always said the UI tech would work in VR, so now we are proving that. I think it could be really nice 'extra' if our webbased shader editor has a VR mode that also works. For now we stick to webXR, but integrating a nativeVR platform probably isin the order of a week of work so its not that hard.

text: Makepad already compiles native for mac, linux and windows, and we have a native build for the quest 'to be completed' as well so its not super hard

elements.text: Makepad already compiles native for mac, linux and windows, and we have a native build for the quest 'to be completed' as well so its not super hard
